questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is a diagnosed case of depression. He is concerned about side effects of his medication and requests you to prescribe a drug least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bupropion

 

Among the given option, Bupropion has the least sexual side effects.

 

Bupropion

 

  • Atypical Antidepressant, NDRI (Norepinephrine Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor)
  • Side effects – insomnia, restlessness, seizures
  • Minimal risk of sexual side effects, weight gain or sedation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escitalopram and Option D. Fluoxetine are SSRIs and they have long-term side effects including low libido, delayed orgasm, and poor erection.

 

Option B. Venlafaxine is a SNRI. It has side effects similar to SSRI and in addition, can cause anticholinergic side effects and hypertension.

questions.text: In indirect inguinal hernia surgery, which nerve is most commonly injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral

 

In the context of Lichtenstein's hernia repair, which is an open mesh repair for inguinal hernias, the ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely to be injured, it was not listed as an option in this question. Therefore, the genitofemoral nerve is the best answer among the given choices.

 

This is because the genitofemoral nerve runs within the spermatic cord, which can be manipulated during the surgery. During the separation of the hernia sac from the spermatic cord, there is a risk of injuring the genitofemoral nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral: The femoral nerve is too large and lies deeper within the body, making it less likely to be injured during an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Obturator: The obturator nerve is not typically associated with inguinal hernia anatomy and is not at risk during these surgeries.

 

Option D. Pudendal: The pudendal nerve is related to the pelvic region and is not typically involved in the anatomy of an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In open inguinal hernia repairs, particularly Lichtenstein's hernia repair, the ilioinguinal nerve >> genitofemoral nerve is at risk of injury due to its location within the spermatic cord and very rarely iliohypogastric nerve can be injured.

 

In laparoscopic hernia repair, there is a risk of injuring nerves such as the lateral cutaneous nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve, and femoral nerve.

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass originating within the middle ear. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

Explanation:

 

The CT scan shows a mass located on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, which is typical of a glomus tympanicum, NOT glomus jugulare.

 

Key points:

 

  • Glomus tympanicum arises on the promontory along the course of Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of IX cranial nerve).
  • It is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm.
  • It appears as a red mass behind the intact tympanic membrane, producing a pulsatile red reflex.
  • CT shows a soft tissue mass confined to the middle ear without erosion of the caroticojugular spine.
  • Glomus jugulare, in contrast, originates from the dome of the jugular bulb, grows into the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and typically erodes the caroticojugular spine (the “phelp sign”).

 

In CT image, there is no obvious erosion of the caroticojugular spine, and the mass is confined to the middle ear promontory, confirming glomus tympanicum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect here — because the tumour is limited to the middle ear promontory without signs of extension into the jugular bulb or jugular foramen. There is no caroticojugular spine erosion.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Does not appear as a mass. It causes abnormal bone deposition near the stapes, leading to conductive hearing loss but not a visible mass.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect — because the finding matches glomus tympanicum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A red mass on the promontory behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no erosion of the caroticojugular spine, indicates glomus tympanicum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • This condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.
  • Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth, especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (known as Meal time syndrome).
  • The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hyper-echoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign body: A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Osteoma of the floor of the mouth: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor. An osteoma of the floor of the mouth would represent an abnormal growth of bone within that specific region. It wouldn't typically be a cause of parotid gland swelling or discomfort. Moreover, osteomas are more radiopaque and wouldn't typically present as hyper-echoic areas on an ultrasound.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

choices.text: Left axis deviation
Mild ST changes in inferior leads
Atrial and ventricular premature contractions
Pansystolic murmur

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pansystolic murmur

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, there are several physiological changes in the cardiovascular system:

 

  1. Clinical Examination:
    • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed.
    • Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces.
    • Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas.
    • Increased and widely split S1 sound.
    • S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split.
    • The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  2. Electrocardiography:
    • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement.
    • Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent.
    • Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
    • Pregnancy does not alter voltage.
    • Tricuspid regurgitation may be present.
    • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left axis deviation: This is a normal change due to the diaphragm being elevated during pregnancy, causing an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the ECG.

 

Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads: These are normal and can be seen due to the changes in heart position and function during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: These are relatively frequent and considered normal in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diastolic and pansystolic murmurs in pregnancy are not normal and should be investigated further.

 

Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adolescents

 

Explanation

 

The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents. The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:

 

  1. Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  2. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  3. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  4. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  5. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  6. Suicide/Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.

 

Now Extended to become – HEEADSS

 

E – Eating and Exercise

 

S - Safety

 

Educational objective: 

 

The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypothermia

 

Osborn waves, also known as J-waves, are characteristic findings on an ECG that are typically associated with hypothermia. These waves appear as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment) and are most evident in moderate to severe cases of hypothermia. The appearance of Osborn waves is thought to be caused by a disparity in the action potential durations between the epicardial and endocardial surfaces of the heart during ventricular repolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: This condition does not typically cause Osborn waves. Instead, hypothyroidism can lead to other ECG changes such as bradycardia, low voltage, and possibly prolonged QT interval.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: This typically leads to a prolonged QT interval but does not cause Osborn waves.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause significant ECG changes, including U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression, it is not associated with Osborn waves.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

J-wave or Osborn wave is seen in cases of moderate or severe hypothermia due to increase in the epicardial potassium current relative to that of endocardium during ventricular repolarization.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for successive recurrent pregnancy losses. On ultrasound, a Mullerian anomaly is suspected. What is the BEST way to confirm this? (NEET PF 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy:

 

  • Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy is considered the best invasive method to confirm the diagnosis of Mullerian anomalies. This approach allows direct visualization of both the internal and external contours of the uterus.
  • During the procedure, hysteroscopy can evaluate the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy can assess the external uterine surface and other pelvic structures.
  • This combination not only confirms the diagnosis but also allows for simultaneous corrective surgery, if necessary (e.g., resecting a uterine septum).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a useful imaging technique for evaluating the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. However, it may not provide detailed information about the external contour of the uterus or distinguish between certain types of Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: While laparoscopy alone can provide information about the external structure of the uterus and other pelvic organs, it does not allow for direct visualization of the endometrial cavity. Combining it with hysteroscopy gives a more comprehensive assessment.

 

Option D. Transvaginal sonography: Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect many uterine anomalies. However, it may not be as definitive as hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, especially for complex anomalies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The best way to confirm a suspected Mullerian anomaly is through hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, which allows for a comprehensive assessment and potential simultaneous treatment.

 

Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole

 

Carbimazole is a medication used to treat hyperthyroidism and is known to cause teratogenic effects if used during pregnancy. It can lead to a rare congenital condition called aplasia cutis congenita, where the baby is born with localized areas of missing skin. The use of carbimazole, especially during the first trimester of pregnancy, is linked with this embryopathy, which highlights the importance of careful medication selection in pregnant women with thyroid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylthiouracil: Although it is an antithyroid drug, it is less commonly used and not specifically associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Option C. Levothyroxine: This is a thyroid hormone replacement and is used to treat hypothyroidism, not associated with congenital defects.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: This option appears to be a distractor as no such common drug name exists that is relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMZ, Carbimazole associated with embryonopathy in first trimester

 

Graves in Pregnancy:

 

<16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)

 

>16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)

 

Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Graves/Chap 384

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Attributable risk

 

The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk. Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Relative risk: Is a measure of the strength of association between exposure and disease, and it compares the risk of disease in exposed individuals to the risk in non-exposed individuals.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk: Is a measure of the Incidence of the disease that is likely to be reduced if the risk factor is modified/eliminated.

 

 

Option D. Odds ratio: Is a measure of the odds of exposure among cases compared to the odds of exposure among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the superficial parotid gland on FNAC? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

 

The preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the parotid gland, as confirmed by fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), is:

 

This is the treatment of choice for a benign parotid tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. It involves the surgical removal of the entire superficial lobe. Enucleation or simple excision is avoided as the tumor has projections (pseudopodia) which may be left behind leading to recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide local incision: This is not typically performed for benign parotid tumors. However, now a days it is becoming an alternate to superficial parotidectomy.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as they are typically not responsive to chemotherapy agents.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as it is generally reserved for cancer treatment and not indicated for benign conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for a benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, providing targeted removal of the entire superficial lobe.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which of the following is the most likely primary cause? (NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

 

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph node is most commonly caused by the anal canal below the dentate line (which marks the border between the anal canal and rectum) goes into the inguinal lymph nodes. As a result, anal cancer occurring below the dentate line can lead to the enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes.

 

However, lymphatics from the anal canal above the dentate line (i.e., the rectum) drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

 

Anal Cancer:  A malignancy that originates in the anal canal or anal margin.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage from the anal canal is to the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, an enlarged inguinal lymph node can indicate the spread of a tumor from the anal region.
  • Clinical Relevance: Patients with anal cancer may present with anal bleeding, pain, or itching. Inguinal lymph node enlargement is an important sign to check for, as it indicates lymphatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the testes.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Therefore, testicular tumors typically spread first to these nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While testicular cancer can metastasize to the inguinal lymph nodes, it's an unusual pathway and typically occurs after a surgical procedure in the groin, which can disrupt the typical lymphatic drainage patterns.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Colon Cancer: Malignancy that arises from the sigmoid portion of the colon.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the sigmoid colon is to the colic nodes and then to the inferior mesenteric nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Inguinal lymph node enlargement is not a typical early site of metastasis for sigmoid colon cancer. More common metastatic sites include the liver and lungs.

 

Option D. Prostate Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the prostate gland.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the prostate is to the internal iliac lymph nodes and then to the external iliac nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While it's possible for prostate cancer to metastasize to the inguinal nodes, it's not the typical pattern of lymphatic spread. Symptoms of prostate cancer include urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A resident physician sustained a needlestick injury while collecting a blood sample from a patient with HIV. It has been decided to provide the physician with post-exposure prophylaxis. What would be the most suitable course of action among the options below? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine+ Tenofovir+ Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Dose - Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + Dolutegravir (50 mg) as 1 tablet/drug OD

 

Duration of PEP is 28 days, irrespective of Regimen type

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A post-operative patient who is immobilized develops sudden onset severe calf pain. What is the next investigation to be done? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duplex USG

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is duplex ultrasound (USG). The clinical picture suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is a common complication in immobilized, post-operative patients.

 

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosing DVT as it combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow and identify any thrombus in the veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography: This is primarily used for pulmonary embolism, not for initial evaluation of suspected DVT.

 

Option C. X-ray: This is not useful for diagnosing DVT, as it does not provide information about the veins or blood flow.

 

Option D. MRI: While MRI can visualize DVT, it is not the first-line investigation due to higher cost, longer procedure time, and less availability compared to duplex ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For post-operative, immobilized patients with sudden onset severe calf pain, suggesting DVT, the next investigation should be a duplex ultrasound, which effectively visualizes the veins and assesses blood flow to confirm the diagnosis. ​

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 96% 

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) stipulates that to achieve the complete elimination of measles, an immunization coverage of at least 96% among children under the age of 1 is necessary. 
  • This high percentage is critical because measles is highly contagious. Such a high coverage rate ensures herd immunity, significantly reducing the chances of measles transmission and protecting those who are not immune.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To eradicate measles, the WHO recommends an immunization coverage of 96% among children under the age of 1, emphasizing the need for near-universal coverage to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the disease.

questions.text: What is the mid arm circumference for severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11.5 cm

 

A mid-arm circumference of less than 11.5 cm is often used as one of the anthropometric indicators for severe acute malnutrition in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition is defined as

 

  1. Weight for height <-3 standard deviation
  2. Mid upper arm circumference <11.5cm
  3. Bilateral pedal edema

choices.text: Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency
Vitamin D deficiency
P. alba (Pityriasis alba)

questions.text: Identify the image and it is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency

 

Casal necklace is a dermatological manifestation observed in pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It presents as a symmetrical rash around the neck region. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis often appears in sun-exposed areas, resulting in the distinctive Casal necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to rickets, a condition characterized by soft, weak bones and skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and widened wrists. The image described does not depict these skeletal changes.

 

Option C. Rickets: Rickets is associated with Vitamin D deficiency and presents with skeletal abnormalities like bowed legs, widened wrists, and delayed growth. The image does not show these features, ruling out rickets as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. P. alba (Pityriasis alba): P. alba, also known as pityriasis alba, is a skin condition characterized by small, raised, white or flesh-colored bumps on the skin, typically affecting children. It is not associated with a specific vitamin deficiency but rather with blocked sweat ducts. The image described in the question is not consistent with pityriasis alba.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal necklace is a classic dermatological manifestation of pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the causes of fall in diastolic blood pressure is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in the lumbar region
  2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors
  3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors
  4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

 

Explanation: 


A fall in diastolic blood pressure primarily occurs due to vasodilation. Two mechanisms listed that cause vasodilation are:

 

1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region: Sympathetic system causes vasoconstriction, so its loss leads to vasodilation

 

3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors: Alpha-1 receptors mediate vasoconstriction, so their blockade causes vasodilation

 

Other Options:


2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors: Incorrect. Beta-1 blockade primarily affects heart rate and contractility, leading to decreased systolic blood pressure, not diastolic pressure.

 

4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors: Incorrect. Beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, so their blockade would cause vasoconstriction and potentially increase diastolic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:


Diastolic blood pressure is primarily affected by vascular tone - vasodilation decreases it (through loss of sympathetic tone or alpha-1 blockade) while vasoconstriction increases it.

questions.text: Identify the marked rib. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4th Posterior

 

Marked rib is 4th posterior.

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior ribs on a chest X-ray are horizontally oriented, while anterior ribs are obliquely oriented.

choices.text: Intact cell organelle
Altered cell shape
Enzyme mediated degradation
Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lecithin

 

Specifically phosphatidylcholine, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant plays a crucial role in reducing surface tension in the alveoli of the lungs, preventing their collapse. A deficiency in lecithin can contribute to respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalin: Cephalin is a type of phospholipid, and while it is present in cell membranes, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not directly associated with respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option B. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is another type of phospholipid found in cell membranes. The deficiency to recycle this lipid due to defective lysosomal enzyme sphingomyelinase cause sphingolipidoses also known as Niemann Pick disease.

 

Option D. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and bacterial membranes. The disease associated with cardiolipins are anti-phospholipid syndrome and Barth syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: Which of these is an indication for giving adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and MRND? (An image of the flap reconstruction was shown).  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extranodal extension

 

Extranodal extension (ENE) refers to the spread of cancer beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding tissues. This feature has recently been added as a significant factor in the staging and management of head and neck cancers, including oral malignancies. ENE is associated with a poorer prognosis due to its aggressive nature and higher likelihood of recurrence. Therefore, it is a major criterion for adjuvant radiotherapy following surgery and MRND (modified radical neck dissection), as radiotherapy can help reduce the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple LN metastases: While having multiple involved lymph nodes is a sign of advanced disease, it alone does not necessarily mandate adjuvant radiotherapy unless combined with other factors, such as large nodal size (>3 cm) or other minor criteria.

Option C. T3 tumor: T3 tumors are generally considered advanced due to their size and extent. However, adjuvant radiotherapy is more strongly indicated when other adverse pathological features, such as ENE or involved surgical margins, are present.

 

Option D. Close margin (1.5-2 mm): Close surgical margins indicate that the tumor was resected near the boundary of normal tissue, increasing the risk of residual disease. However, a close margin alone is not as critical as an involved margin (<1 mm) and typically requires radiotherapy only if combined with other adverse features.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Extranodal extension is a key indication for adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after surgical resection and MRND due to its significant impact on prognosis and risk of recurrence.

choices.text: Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism
It is a histone deacetylase and it causes chromatin condensation
It increases the life span
It is stimulated by niacinamide

questions.text: True about sirtuins are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is stimulated by niacinamide

 

This statement is incorrect. Sirtuins require NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) as a substrate for their enzymatic activity. During the process, NAD+ is converted to nicotinamide (niacinamide). The presence of niacinamide actually inhibits the activity of sirtuins, not stimulates it (option D is false).

 

Other Options

 

Sirtuins (Silent Mating Type Information Regulation Proteins) are a family of proteins that play a role in cellular regulation and are involved in various biological processes, including aging, transcription, and stress resistance.

 

Option A. Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism: Sirtuins improve glucose metabolism by increasing insulin sensitivity, thus supporting the efficient utilization of glucose in the body (option A is true).

 

Option B. It is a histone deacetylase and it causes chromatin condensation: Sirtuins have histone deacetylase activity. This activity removes acetyl groups from histones, resulting in a positive charge on the histones. The positive charge leads to tight binding of histones to DNA due to charge-charge interactions, leading to chromatin condensation (option B is true).

 

Option C. It increases the life span: Sirtuins are associated with the delay of the aging process and have been shown to extend the lifespan in various organisms by participating in DNA base excision repair and other cellular processes (option C is true).

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Sirtuins are involved in improving insulin sensitivity, supporting glucose metabolism, causing chromatin condensation through histone deacetylation, and extending lifespan. However, they are not stimulated by niacinamide; instead, niacinamide inhibits their activity.

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical

 

According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

 

M=Midline, L=Lateral

 

M1: defect up to 3 cm below xiphoid

 

M3: Defect within 3 cm of umbilicus (above or below)

 

M5: Defect up to 3 cm above pubis

 

M2: Defects between M1 and M3

 

M4: Defects between M3 and M5.

questions.text: Diarrhoea by cholera toxin involves which receptors:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

Cholera toxin binds specifically to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding is the initial step in the pathogenesis of cholera. The toxin's B subunits bind to GM1 gangliosides, facilitating the entry of the A subunit into the cells. The A subunit then activates adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels and subsequent chloride and water secretion, causing diarrhea.


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GD-1b Ganglioside Receptor: The GD-1b ganglioside receptor is not the target for cholera toxin. This receptor has other physiological roles in the body and is not primarily associated with the mechanism of cholera toxin-induced diarrhea.

 

Option C. GM2 Ganglioside Receptor: GM2 ganglioside receptors are not involved in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin. They have different functions and are not known to interact with cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of diarrhea.

 

Option D. GM3 Ganglioside Receptor: While GM3 ganglioside is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor that cholera toxin binds to. The specific interaction between cholera toxin and GM1 gangliosides is critical for the toxin's effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding of cholera toxin to GM1 facilitates its entry into the cells, where it exerts its toxic effects by activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). Elevated cAMP levels lead to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: Vaccine kept at the lowest level inside an Ice lined refrigerator (ILR) at PHC: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) OPV

 

In an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR), which is commonly used at Primary Health Centers (PHCs) to store vaccines, the temperature varies from 2°C at the bottom to 8°C at the top. Vaccines that require colder temperatures, closer to 2°C, are stored at the lowest level of the refrigerator because cold air settles down.

 

OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine): OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR because it requires a colder environment. It can even tolerate freezing temperatures and can be stored in a deep freezer at -15°C to -25°C, making it suitable for the coldest section of the refrigerator.

 

  • Lyophilized vaccines like BCG, measles, and rotaviral vaccine are also stored at lower levels since they need a stable and colder temperature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCG: While BCG is a lyophilized vaccine and is stored at a lower level, it is not specifically the answer for this question as OPV is more specifically associated with the lowest level due to its freezing tolerance.

 

Option C. DPT: DPT vaccine is stored at the upper levels of the ILR where temperatures are closer to 6-8°C. This vaccine does not require the colder conditions found at the bottom of the refrigerator.

 

Option D. Rotaviral vaccine: Similar to BCG, the rotaviral vaccine is a lyophilized vaccine stored lower in the ILR, but OPV is the more critical vaccine stored at the lowest level due to its requirement for cold and even freezing conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions, ranging from 2°C and even tolerating freezing conditions, ensuring vaccine potency and effectiveness.

questions.text: What is the latest online software introduced by the government under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) to monitor patients with tuberculosis? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) NIKSHAY

 

  • NIKSHAY is the latest online software introduced by the Indian government under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) to monitor and manage patients with tuberculosis. This software facilitates the tracking of TB patients from diagnosis through treatment, ensuring that all cases are adequately monitored to achieve the goal of TB elimination.
  • NIKSHAY (Nikshay) aims to improve the surveillance, monitoring, and treatment of TB patients by providing a centralized platform for data collection and management. It enables health workers to record details of TB cases, track patient progress, and ensure that treatment protocols are followed, which is crucial for the effective management of TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NISCHAY:   This refers to a pregnancy test kit and is unrelated to the monitoring of TB patients.

 

Option C. E-DOTS:  Electronic Directly Observed Therapy (eDOT) aka Virtual Directly Observed Therapy, is an approach for treating TB where healthcare providers observe patients taking their medication through real-time or prerecorded video.

 

Option D. NIKUSTH:  This software is used for monitoring leprosy patients, not tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIKSHAY - Monitoring TB patients.

 

NIKUSTH - Monitoring leprosy patients.

                                          

NISCHAY - Pregnancy test kit.

 

E-DOTS - Virtual Directly Observed Therapy DOT.

choices.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

 

Wound dehiscence is the partial or total separation of layers of a surgical wound. Various signs can indicate this complication, particularly in a post-operative patient who is hypotensive:

 

This type of drainage, which is composed of both blood and serous fluid, can indicate that the wound layers are not properly adhered and may be a sign of impending or actual dehiscence. It's considered a "sure sign" because it often precedes the wound actually coming apart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased bowel sounds: While changes in bowel sounds can be associated with various abdominal conditions like intestinal obstruction, they are not a specific sign of wound dehiscence.

 

Option B. Persistent abdominal pain: Pain is a nonspecific symptom that can be associated with many post-operative complications, including wound dehiscence, but on its own is not a definitive sign.

 

Option D. Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges: While this can occur with wound dehiscence, it is more of a late sign when the wound has already dehisced significantly.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Serosanguinous drainage from the surgical wound is a "sure sign" of wound dehiscence and warrants immediate medical evaluation to prevent further complications.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial

 

The pedigree chart shown in Image 2 demonstrates a clear pattern of mitochondrial inheritance. Key characteristics of this inheritance pattern are:

 

  1. Maternal transmission: The disease is passed down exclusively from affected mothers to all their children (both sons and daughters).
  2. No paternal transmission: Affected fathers do not pass the condition to any of their offspring.
  3. All offspring of an affected mother are affected: This is because all mitochondria in a zygote come from the egg cell.

 

In the pedigree, we can see that in each generation, affected mothers (filled circles) transmit the condition to all their children, while affected fathers (filled squares) do not pass it on to any of their children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal Dominant: Incorrect. This pattern would show affected individuals in every generation, but both males and females would be able to transmit the condition to their offspring.

 

Option B. Autosomal Recessive: Incorrect. This pattern typically shows skip generations and requires both parents to be carriers or affected for the offspring to be affected.

 

Option C. X linked recessive: Incorrect. This pattern would show predominantly affected males, with females as carriers, and no male-to-male transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission of a trait to all offspring, with no paternal transmission, due to the exclusive inheritance of mitochondria from the mother's egg cell

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used for cancers can cause hand-foot syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Hand-foot syndrome, also known as palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia, is a side effect of certain chemotherapy drugs. It is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. This condition is most commonly associated with pyrimidine analogs, such as 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and its prodrug capecitabine. Capecitabine is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent for various cancers, including colorectal and breast cancer, and is well known for causing hand-foot syndrome as a dose-limiting toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide:  This is an alkylating agent used in cancer treatment and does not typically cause hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option B. Bleomycin:  An antitumor antibiotic used in cancer therapy, primarily associated with pulmonary toxicity rather than hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: A microtubule inhibitor used in cancer treatment, which can cause peripheral neuropathy and hypersensitivity reactions, but is not commonly associated with hand-foot syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine, a pyrimidine analog, is the cancer drug most commonly associated with causing hand-foot syndrome, characterized by redness, swelling, and pain in the hands and feet.

questions.text: Which nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

Chronic alcoholism often leads to poor dietary intake, resulting in various nutritional deficiencies.

 

One of the most significant deficiencies in chronic alcoholics is niacin (vitamin B3). Niacin deficiency leads to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

The dermatitis in pellagra is specifically photodermatitis, meaning it occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the neck and dorsum of the hands. The rash is pruritic and eczematous, commonly presenting as Casal's necklace around the neck and gauntlet sign on the hands.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Deficiency in riboflavin (vitamin B2) typically leads to symptoms such as cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis but does not cause the characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin deficiency.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid deficiency often presents with megaloblastic anemia and glossitis, not with the dermatological symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the cardiovascular and nervous systems, rather than causing the dermatological symptoms seen with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics, leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis is photodermatitis, presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on sun-exposed areas like the neck and dorsum of the hands. ​

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below. Identify the diagnosis: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

SCURVY

 

  • It is the deficiency of vitamin C, causing defect in the osteoid formation. 
  • The rosary found in this condition is sharp and tender. 
  • Radiological Features: 
    • Sclerosed Margins of Epiphysis
    • Osteopenia – ground glass appearance – 1st sign – thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).
    • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.
    • Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis.
    • Scurvy line or scorbutic zone (Trummerfeld’s zone) – radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone.
    • Margins of the epiphysis appears sclerotic, termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (Ring sign).
    • Lateral metaphyseal spur (Pelkan spur) at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of zone of provisional calcification and periosteal reaction.
    • Corner or angle sign is peripheral metaphyseal cleft.
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage in lower end of femur and tibia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets. In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones. There is irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis, and thin and weak new trabeculae. On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped. The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance); and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis. Also called as marble bone disease, it is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen. 

 

 

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia. Also known as Pyle disease, it is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by flaring of the ends of long bones with relative constriction and sclerosis of the diaphysis and mild cranial sclerosis. The flared metaphyses are relatively lucent. The patients are often asymptomatic, although genu valgus deformity may be a feature. Patients present with short-limb dwarfism characterized by coxa vara, and spinal abnormalities. Radiographs reveals bulbous expansion of metaphysis. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image in the question is suggestive of features due to vitamin C deficiency, scurvy. 
  • Following are the features seen in a patient with scurvy on a plain radiograph:

questions.text: Cord clamping in the 3rd stage of labor is done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-3 mins

 

The correct answer is 1-3 mins. Delayed cord clamping is recommended by health guidelines to improve neonatal outcomes. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines delayed cord clamping as occurring between 30 to 60 seconds after birth, whereas American guidelines suggest waiting for 1 to 3 minutes. The common practice derived from both recommendations is to wait at least one minute.

 

Delayed Cord Clamping: This practice allows more blood to transfer from the placenta to the newborn, which can provide significant health benefits such as improved iron stores and reduced risk of anemia. Clamping the cord within 1-3 minutes after birth falls within the recommended window for delayed cord clamping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate: Immediate cord clamping, done within seconds after birth, is considered early cord clamping and does not provide the benefits associated with delayed cord clamping.

 

Option C. 5 mins: Waiting for 5 minutes is considered too long and is not a standard recommendation by any major health guidelines for delayed cord clamping.

 

Option D. Once cord pulsations stop: While waiting until cord pulsations stop can be an indicator, it is not the standard timing recommendation and may vary more widely than the 1-3 minute window suggested by guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed cord clamping is recommended to be performed 1-3 minutes after birth to optimize neonatal health outcomes.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

 

A ranula is a type of mucocele found on the floor of the mouth, associated with the sublingual gland. During the surgical excision of a ranula along with the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is at risk of being injured. The lingual nerve runs close to the sublingual gland and is responsible for sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Due to its proximity, it is the structure most likely to be damaged during such surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mylohyoid muscle: The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is situated below the sublingual gland. It is less likely to be injured during the excision of a ranula as the procedure primarily involves the tissues above this muscle.

 

Option C. Submental artery: The submental artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the mylohyoid muscle. While it is in the general area, it is not as closely associated with the sublingual gland as the lingual nerve is, making it less likely to be injured during this specific procedure.

 

Option D. Sublingual artery: The sublingual artery supplies blood to the sublingual gland and the surrounding tissues. Although it is close to the surgical site, the risk of injury to the lingual nerve is higher due to its course and proximity to the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

choices.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery
It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

 

Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It can spread through both hematogenous routes and lymphatics, and treatment typically involves a combination of surgery and chemotherapy. However, while it is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, it is not the most common. That distinction belongs to neuroblastoma.

 

It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children: This statement is incorrect. While Wilms tumor is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in pediatric patients is neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spread by lymphatics: Nephroblastoma can spread via lymphatics, usually involving regional lymph nodes first. Although hematogenous spread is more common, lymphatic spread does occur.

 

Option B. Early lung metastasis: Wilms tumor often metastasizes to the lungs early in its course. Children diagnosed with Wilms tumor typically undergo chest imaging to check for lung metastasis.

 

Option C. Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery: The standard treatment for Wilms tumor involves surgical removal of the tumor followed by chemotherapy to eliminate any remaining cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroblastoma is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, not Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).
